questions.text: Emphasis shifted from urban to rural services
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Equitable distribution: While equitable distribution is a crucial principle in healthcare, it primarily focuses on ensuring fair access to healthcare services across different population groups, regardless of geographic location or socioeconomic status. It specifically address the shift of emphasis from urban to rural services.

Explanation of incorrect options

Community participation (Option B): Community participation involves engaging local communities in decision-making processes and empowering them to take ownership of their health. While community participation is important in primary healthcare delivery, it does not directly address the shift of emphasis from urban to rural services.

Intersectoral coordination (Option C): Intersectoral coordination involves collaboration across different sectors, such as health, education, agriculture, and transportation, to address the social determinants of health and promote well-being. While intersectoral coordination is important for comprehensive healthcare delivery, it does not specifically address the shift of emphasis from urban to rural services.

Appropriate technology (Option D): Appropriate technologies are cost-effective, easy to use, and suitable for the local context. Therefore, it does not address the shift of emphasis from urban to rural services.

questions.text: The Date set globally for the achievement of SDG is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were adopted by all United Nations Member States in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Therefore, the target year set globally for the achievement of the SDGs is 2030.

questions.text: Which Goal in SDG is directly related to health
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Goal 3 of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is directly related to health. Goal 3 aims to "ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages". It encompasses various targets related to improving maternal health, reducing child mortality, combating communicable diseases, ensuring access to essential healthcare services, and addressing non-communicable diseases.

Explanation of incorrect options

Goal 1 (Option A): Goal 1 aims to "end poverty in all its forms everywhere". While poverty and health are interconnected, Goal 1 primarily focuses on poverty eradication rather than health outcomes.

Goal 2 (Option B): Goal 2 aims to "end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture". While nutrition is related to health, Goal 2 primarily focuses on food security and agriculture rather than health outcomes.

Goal 4 (Option D): Goal 4 aims to "ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all". While education is important for health literacy and health outcomes, Goal 4 primarily focuses on education rather than health outcomes.

questions.text: Under NREGA, a household is entitled to how many days of work in a year
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA), a household is entitled to a minimum of 100 days of guaranteed wage employment in a financial year. This means that if a household demands employment under MGNREGA, the government is obligated to provide them with work for at least 100 days in a year.

questions.text: The Millennium Summit was held in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Millennium Summit was held in New York City, United States, from September 6 to 8, 2000. The summit was convened by the United Nations and marked the largest gathering of world leaders in history up to that time. It aimed to discuss and address various global challenges and set the agenda for the new millennium.

questions.text: The Millennium Development Goals were launched by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) were indeed launched by the United Nations in the year 2000. They were a set of eight international development goals aimed at addressing various global challenges such as poverty, hunger, disease, gender inequality, and environmental degradation by the target year of 2015.

questions.text: The Millennium Development Goals are based upon
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) were based upon the United Nations Millennium Declaration, which was adopted by 189 United Nations member states during the Millennium Summit in September 2000. The declaration outlined a commitment to work towards specific goals aimed at addressing poverty, hunger, disease, gender inequality, and other global challenges by the year

Explanation of incorrect options

WHO health records (Option A): The Millennium Development Goals were not based on WHO health records. While the World Health Organization (WHO) provides valuable data and guidance for global health initiatives, the MDGs were established by the United Nations based on broader socio-economic development goals.

UNICEF health criteria (Option B): While UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, contributes to global efforts related to child health and welfare, the Millennium Development Goals were not specifically based on UNICEF health criteria. The MDGs were derived from the broader Millennium Declaration adopted by the United Nations.

SEARO Millennium Declaration (Option D): SEARO refers to the South-East Asia Regional Office of the World Health Organization (WHO). The Millennium Development Goals were not based on a declaration specific to the SEARO region. Instead, they were based on the United Nations Millennium Declaration, which had a global scope and was adopted by member states worldwide.

questions.text: The Multipurpose scheme in India was introduced by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The multipurpose scheme in India was introduced by the Kartar Singh Committee.

Explanation of incorrect options

Bhore Committee (Option A): The Bhore Committee, formed in 1943, was responsible for making recommendations for a comprehensive health plan for India, leading to the establishment of the healthcare infrastructure and the establishment of the Central Health Education Bureau.

Shrivastav Committee (Option C): The Shrivastav Committee, also known as the Health Survey and Development Committee, was appointed in 1943 to assess the health conditions in India and make recommendations for their improvement. It led to the establishment of the Directorate General of Health Services.

Mudaliar Committee (Option D): The Mudaliar Committee, formed in 1959, focused on medical education in India. It made recommendations to improve medical education and training, leading to the establishment of new medical colleges and the restructuring of the medical curriculum.

questions.text: The ROME scheme was introduced by the recommendations of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ROME (Revised Outline of Medical Education) scheme was introduced based on the recommendations of the Shrivastav Committee.

Explanation of incorrect options

Chadha (Option A): There is no known association between the Chadha committee and the ROME scheme. The Chadha Committee was appointed in 1961 to review medical education and medical manpower needs in India.

Mukherji (Option B): The Mukherji Committee, also known as the Health Survey and Planning Committee, was appointed in 1961 to review the progress of health services in India. It made recommendations for the expansion and improvement of health services.

Kartar Singh (Option C): Kartar Singh Committee is associated with the introduction of the multipurpose scheme in India, not the ROME scheme.

questions.text: The Rural Health Scheme was introduced by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The rural health scheme was introduced based on the recommendations of the Srivastava Committee.

The Shrivastav Committee, also known as the Health Survey and Development Committee, was appointed in 1943 to assess the health conditions in India and make recommendations for their improvement. It led to the establishment of the Directorate General of Health Services.

Explanation of incorrect options

Bhore Committee (Option A): The Bhore Committee, officially known as the Health Survey and Development Committee, was formed in 1943 and made recommendations for the development of health services in India. However, it did not specifically introduce a rural health scheme.

Mukherjee Committee (Option B): The Mukherjee Committee, also known as the Health Survey and Planning Committee, was appointed in 1961 to review the progress of health services in India. It made recommendations for the expansion and improvement of health services, but it did not introduce a rural health scheme.

Mudaliar Committee (Option D): The Mudaliar Committee was appointed in 1959 to review medical education and recommend improvements. It focused on medical education rather than the introduction of a rural health scheme.

choices.text: MPW in health and family planning

questions.text: Universal health coverage of India was recently approved by which health committee
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) framework for India was recently approved by the High-Level Expert Group (HLEG) on Universal Health Coverage. This group was established to provide recommendations on achieving universal health coverage in India.

Explanation of incorrect options

Medical Education Health Group (Option A): This group primarily focuses on medical education, rather than the broader concept of universal health coverage.

MPW in Health and Family Planning (Option B): The Multipurpose Health Worker (MPW) program focuses on the role of health workers in providing family planning services and basic health care, rather than the comprehensive framework of universal health coverage.

Health Survey and Development Committee (Option D): The Health Survey and Development Committee (commonly known as the Bhore Committee) was formed in 1943 and made recommendations for the development of health services in India. While it laid the foundation for healthcare in India, it did not specifically approve or endorse universal health coverage as recently proposed by the High-Level Expert Group.

questions.text: The Concept of multipurpose workers was given by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The concept of multipurpose workers in the healthcare sector was proposed by the Kartar Singh Committee. This committee was appointed by the Government of India in 1973 to review the status of medical and public health services in the country and to make recommendations for their improvement. One of the key recommendations of the Kartar Singh Committee was the introduction of multipurpose health workers to address the healthcare needs of rural and underserved communities efficiently.

Explanation of incorrect options

Mudaliar Committee (Option A): The Mudaliar Committee, also known as the Health Survey and Development Committee, was established in 1943 to survey the health conditions in India and make recommendations for their improvement. However, it did not specifically propose the concept of multipurpose workers.

Srivastava Committee (Option B): The Srivastava Committee was constituted by the Government of India in 1975 to examine the structure, organization, and functioning of the Directorate General of Health Services (DGHS). It did not propose the concept of multipurpose workers.

Mukherjee Committee (Option D): The Mukherjee Committee, officially known as the National Commission on Macroeconomics and Health, was constituted by the Government of India in 2005 to assess the macroeconomic consequences of health problems in India. It focused on broader health policy issues and did not specifically propose the concept of multipurpose workers.

choices.text: Ayurvedic, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, Homeopathy

questions.text: The Department of AYUSH controls which of the following medicines
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Department of AYUSH (Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy) in India is responsible for the promotion and regulation of traditional systems of medicine, including Ayurveda, Yoga, Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha, and Homeopathy.

Explanation of incorrect options

Allopathic, Ayurvedic, Unani, Siddha, Homeopathy (Option A): This option includes allopathic medicine along with traditional systems of medicine. However, the Department of AYUSH specifically focuses on traditional systems of medicine and does not regulate allopathic medicine, which is under the purview of other government departments such as the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

Ayurvedic, Unani, Siddha, Homeopathy (Option B): This option excludes Yoga and Naturopathy, which are also part of the Department of AYUSH.

Ayurvedic, Yoga, Siddha, Homeopathy (Option C): This option excludes Unani, which is also regulated by the Department of AYUSH.
